channel.title: Sec3d
channel.description: Building applications, securing infrastructure and applications, and everything in-between.

item.title: Sigstore - Signature Sorcery
item.description: Sigstore is an open source project enabling anyone to sign and validate software releases, including container images. This article takes a closer look at Sigstore and some of the innovation happening around the project.
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Automating Fortinet FortiGate devices with Ansible
item.description: A recent FortiOS vulnerability is being actively exploited. Ansible can be used to implement a mitigation.
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Measuring Essential Eight Assessment Activity
item.description: In the last article I looked at automating some of the tests available for Windows servers and desktops in the ACSC Essential Eight assessment guide. This article looks at how we can measure assessment activity - how often are we assessing systems, and are they passing the tests?
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Automating the Essential Eight Assessment Guide
item.description: Recently the Australian Cyber Security Centre released an Essential Eight assessment guide. This article looks at automating some of the tests in the guide with Ansible.
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Improved Functional Verification Testing with Ansible
item.description: Ansible provides a way to automate functional verification tests. This article looks at an improved approach to automating functional verification tests that I introduced in an earlier article.
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Functional Verification Testing with Ansible
item.description: Functional verification provides a way that we can attest to the configuration of a device or system, and verify compliance controls. This article looks at a functional verification approach using Ansible.
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Up and running with the File Access Policy Analyzer
item.description: A quick look at the File Access Policy Analyzer, an open source tool simplifying application control implementation
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Automated security patching with Ansible
item.description: RSA Conference 2022 again highlighted that many data breaches are due to unpatched systems. In this article I look at some of the technologies available to help organisations ensure that updates are applied across their hybrid cloud environments
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Access & Agents
item.description: Many organisations take the same approach to securing virtual machines, which I call 'Access & Agents'. While effective for virtual machines and other legacy infrastructure, this approach doesn't translate across to containers and Kubernetes, and this article looks at why.
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Scanning the OpenShift Internal Registry
item.description: Did you know that you can scan the internal OpenShift registry for security issues? Read on to find out how.
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Scanning Quay.io private repositories for CVEs
item.description: A quick guide on how to integrate a Kubernetes-native security platform with quay.io private repositories
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Automating application control
item.description: Automation allows organisations to scale security workflows across hybrid cloud environments. In this article I take a closer look at automating application control, and how you can use Ansible roles to create reusable automation content.
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Kubernetes-native security and least surprise
item.description: What does it mean to be "Kubernetes-native"? And what does Kubernetes-native security look like?
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Application control and integrity checks
item.description: Injecting integrity checks to application control processes is a winning security combination. Application control allows you to specify that only certain processes can execute on a system - but how do you know they are the right processes? How can you ensure that the code that you want to execute is the code that actually executes?
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Application control for everyone
item.description: Application control seems to be one of those elusive security controls that organisations spend years chasing. How can we validate which processes are authorised to run on a system, and then enforce this?
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)

item.title: Compliance is mislabelled
item.description: Compliance evokes images of checking boxes. The real purpose of IT system compliance is risk migitation, and it probably just needs a better name
item.author: dev@stb.id.au (Shane Boulden)
